gw.api.web.account

Class AbstractBalancesView

  • java.lang.Object
    • gw.api.web.account.AbstractBalancesView
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    AccountBalancesView, PolicyPeriodBalancesView

    public abstract class AbstractBalancesView
extends java.lang.Object
    Alternative balance methods which should not return negative numbers in case of prepayment.

    These methods are written to achieve the following desiderata (refer also to CC-30034): 1) the outstanding amount is never negative when it can be covered by the unbilled & billed amounts 2) billed is never negative 3) prepayments should never cause unbilled to become negative (although obviously negative policyChanges may).

    Author:
    efoley

      MonetaryAmount getAdjustedBilledAmount()
      Returns the Billed balance for the given t-account owner, unless the due balance is negative.
      MonetaryAmount getAdjustedOutstandingAmount()
      Returns the Outstanding (billed + due) balance for the given t-account owner, unless the due balance is negative.
      MonetaryAmount getAdjustedUnbilledAmount()
      Returns the Unbilled balance for the given t-account owner, unless the total of the billed and due balances is negative.
      protected TAccountOwner tAccountOwner()

    • Method Detail

      • tAccountOwner

        protected TAccountOwner tAccountOwner()

      • getAdjustedUnbilledAmount

        public MonetaryAmount getAdjustedUnbilledAmount()
        Returns the Unbilled balance for the given t-account owner, unless the total of the billed and due balances is negative. In that case, then the negative total for billed and due is added to the positive unbilled amount.

        Example:

        $100 Charge is created: $100 debit in unbilled, $100 credit in revenue (unbilled balance is $100, billed balance is $0, due balance is $0)

        $100 Charge is paid: $100 debit in unapplied, $100 credit in due (unbilled balance is $100, billed balance is $0, due balance is -$100)

        The raw unbilled amount is $100, but the adjusted unbilled amount is $100 + ($0 - $100) = $0

        Returns:
        the adjusted amount

      • adjustUnbilledAmount

        protected static MonetaryAmount adjustUnbilledAmount(MonetaryAmount unbilledAmount,
                                  MonetaryAmount billedAmount,
                                  MonetaryAmount dueAmount)

      • getAdjustedBilledAmount

        public MonetaryAmount getAdjustedBilledAmount()
        Returns the Billed balance for the given t-account owner, unless the due balance is negative. In that case, then the negative due amount is added to the positive billed amount.

        Example:

        $100 Charge is created: $100 debit in unbilled, $100 credit in revenue (unbilled balance is $100, billed balance is $0, due balance is $0)

        $100 Charge is billed: $100 debit in billed, $100 credit in unbilled (unbilled balance is $0, billed balance is $100, due balance is -$0)

        $100 Charge is paid: $100 debit in unapplied, $100 credit in due (unbilled balance is $0, billed balance is $100, due balance is -$100)

        The raw billed amount is $100, but the adjusted billed amount is $100 - $100 = $0

        Returns:
        the adjusted amount

      • adjustBilledAmount

        protected static MonetaryAmount adjustBilledAmount(MonetaryAmount billedAmount,
                                MonetaryAmount dueAmount)

      • getAdjustedOutstandingAmount

        public MonetaryAmount getAdjustedOutstandingAmount()
        Returns the Outstanding (billed + due) balance for the given t-account owner, unless the due balance is negative. In that case, $0 is returned if billed + due is a negative amount.

        Example:

        $100 Charge is created: $100 debit in unbilled, $100 credit in revenue (unbilled balance is $100, billed balance is $0, due balance is $0)

        $50 Charge is billed: $50 debit in billed, $50 credit in unbilled (unbilled balance is $0, billed balance is $50, due balance is -$0)

        $100 Charge is paid: $100 debit in unapplied, $100 credit in due (unbilled balance is $50, billed balance is $50, due balance is -$100)

        The raw outstanding amount is -$50, but the adjusted outstanding amount is max(-$50, $0) = $0

        Returns:
        the adjusted amount

      • adjustOutstandingAmount

        protected static MonetaryAmount adjustOutstandingAmount(MonetaryAmount billedAmount,
                                     MonetaryAmount dueAmount)
